lines.text: I wouldn't extort a nickel from my worst enemy. That's where I draw the line.
Well, I'll tell you, Jake. I knew a whore once. For the right amount of money, she'd piss in a guy's face. But she wouldn't shit on his chest. You see, that's where she drew the line.
I hope she wasn't too much of a disappointment to you.
What I do for a living may not be very reputable... but I am. In this town I'm the leper with the most fingers.
You are very successful.
Oh, I can't complain.
Does that mean you are happy?
Who can answer that question off the top of their head?
Anyone who's happy.
Come on, Gittes. There you were, consorting with a known hoodlum under grand jury investigation... and known to be friendly with your client, Jake Berman.
So, what?
So, either you were doing business with Mickey, or, uh...
Or what?
We got a vice officer who swears you approached him and fondled his privates in the men's room.
[Loach breaks out laughing]

[to Policeman]
How was it for you?
You know something, Jake, you might think you know what's going on around here, but... you don't.
You can't trust a guy who's never lost anything.

You can follow the action, which gets you good pictures. You can follow your instincts, which'll probably get you in trouble. Or, you can follow the money, which nine times out of ten will get you closer to the truth.
The problem with you, kid, is you don't know who you're kiddin'.
Does it ever go away?
What's that?
The past.
I think you have to work real hard on that one.
[last lines]
Katherine?
[she turns to look at him]
It never goes away.
Where were we?
Well, I was accusing you of murder, Mr. Berman.
Call me Jake.

[looking at photos of mystery blonde]
Did you follow her?
What for? You told me to follow Berman.
Berman had a 2 o'clock appointment at his lawyer's, Ralph. You don't follow somebody when you know where they're goin'!
But you said STAY WITH Berman!

[disgusted]
Who the FUCK is this woman?
Who's THAT woman?
We're talkin' about oil here, right, Ty?

Obviously. Mr. Rawley believes there's oil under the subdivision. He's endangering hundreds of lives drilling under those homes, with all the seismic activity. He's whipstocking! Someone has got to stop him!

Well, I can't do that, Ty. Nobody can. Guys like Rawley don't get arrested; they get streets named after them. In this type of situation, it's best just to leave it alone. Rawley's stealin' from Berman. It's a big thief stealin' from a little thief. Who are we to quarrel?

the air smells better, it's harder to see that the oil rigs outnumber the palm tress; it's almost like the good old days, at least the way I'd like to remember them. But stay in this business long enough and every street leads to a place you'd like to forget, every case brings back memories of what you should have done & what might have been, and every skirt reminds you of another woman... or, if you've got it bad enough, the same woman.
I don't want to live in the past, Khan. I just don't want to lose it.
I'm trying to be a gentleman here. Now, get on your knees, put your ass in the air, and don't move until I say to.
Gosh dang it.

Without my oil, you got no automobiles. Without automobiles, you got no road construction, no sidewalks, no city lights, no gas stations, no automotive service, and no Berman subdivision stuck out in the tules, because nobody can get there. Then Mr. Berman's out of business, before he even gets in business. The name of the game is oil, John.
What business you got with Jake Berman?
Jake Berman is 100% legitimate.
What do you call legitimate?
I can tell YOU what I DON'T consider legitimate.
Must be a short list.
Blackmail.
Isn't it a fact, Mr. Gittes, that you're out on bail, having been arrested at the Green Parrot Bar & Grill?
Wait a minute. Your Honor, the witness has been CHARGED, not convicted.
What's the charge?
The charge?
YES. The charge.
Well, that, uh, Mr. Gittes was fondling... the private parts of a vice officer in the Men's Room of the Green Parrot Bar & Grill.
[gasps and laughter fill the court room]
Objection, Your Honor.

I'm with you, Mr. Weinberger. I have NO idea what you thought you could do with this kind of evidence, Mr. Hannah. It certainly has no place in MY court room. Do yourself a favor. The next time, you be sure you've got a case. That's about it for this hearing.
Maybe I didn't tell the whole truth at the prelinenary hearing, but there's one thing I learned about the truth... a little bit goes a long way.
How do you know he didn't have the gun with him?
Oh, I'd never frisk him before I let him walk in on his wife hanging on the headboard while some guy was slammin' her into the wall, Lou!
Does that mean he wants you to prove your own client is guilty of murder?
Yeah.
Well, 's that ethical?
Larry, he's a lawyer.
Does it ever go away?
What's that?
The past.
Well, I think you have to work real hard at that.
I'm used to seein' the intimate details of people's lives, but lookin' at a guy's x-rays is as intimate as it gets. It's the kind of thing most guys don't even tell their wives about.
Most cops' ethics are like the car they drive... black and white.
Yeah, I'll gonna have more lawsuits than Carter has liver pills.
